Refer to the exhibit. Which route will be found in the routing table of the Main router?

discussion.content: Sorry never mind I took a closer look at the graphic there are 2 sub-interfaces on one of the ports.

Looking at the router there are only 4 interfaces. The serial interface would be IP NAT Outside. So the answer should be 3. Unless the question is worded incorrectly and it is really asking how many interfaces will be involved in the NAT process. Or am I looking at this wrong?

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. How many interfaces on R1 should be configured as ip nat inside to grant external access to the entire network?
//IMG//

Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer is troubleshooting an Internet connectivity problem on the computer. What is causing the problem?
//IMG//

discussion.content: The answer is actually B. The router interface Fa0/0 has an ip address of 192.168.1.1 which makes that the default gateway on the pc's on that LAN. The IP address has been manually misconfigured.
The correct answer is C. The IP address of the PC (192.168.11.2/24) is not on the same network with its gateway 192.168.1.1

comments.content: IMHO this would only be true if there is a gateway and dns available on the 192.168.11.0/24 network. Since this is not mentioned, the correct answer would be B (someone Fat Fingered the ip address)

discussion.content: Guys im writing CISCO ICND2 tommorrow i hope this website will assit me

Answer D is correct:

SPAN monitor session A function enabled in a Cisco switch that intercepts a defined subset
of frames being sent through the switch (as defined by the SPAN monitor session), directing
a copy of those frames out a certain port, so that other tools (like network analyzers and
intrusion protection systems) can examine the frames.

questions.question_text: Which feature can you use to monitor traffic on a switch by replicating it to another port or ports on the same switch?
What is a valid HSRP virtual MAC address?

discussion.content:
Answer: D
Explanation:
Hot Standby Router Protocol Features and Functionality
http://www.cisco.com/en/US/tech/tk648/tk362/technologies_tech_note09186a0080094a91.shtml
HSRP Addressing
In most cases when you configure routers to be part of an HSRP group, they listen for the HSRP
MAC address for that group as well as their own burned-in MAC address. The exception is routers whose Ethernet controllers only recognize a single MAC address (for example, the Lance controller on the Cisco 2500 and Cisco 4500 routers). These routers use the HSRP MAC address when they are the Active router, and their burned-in address when they are not.
HSRP uses the following MAC address on all media except Token Ring:
0000.0c07.ac** (where ** is the HSRP group number)
The correct answer is D. 0000.0C07.AC15 , but without letter D
Correction: Should not say "Correct Answer: Explanation "
This should be D. 0000.0C07.AC15 D - Not sure why it says "Discussion"
